docblock.description: Get indexed SNMP values (first degree)
docblock.long-description:
Walks the SNMP tree returning an array of key => value pairs.

This is a first degree walk and it will throw an exception if there is more that one degree of values.

I.e. the following query with sample results:

walk1d( '.1.0.8802.1.1.2.1.3.7.1.4' )

  .1.0.8802.1.1.2.1.3.7.1.4.1 = STRING: "GigabitEthernet1/0/1"
  .1.0.8802.1.1.2.1.3.7.1.4.2 = STRING: "GigabitEthernet1/0/2"
  .1.0.8802.1.1.2.1.3.7.1.4.3 = STRING: "GigabitEthernet1/0/3"
  .....

would yield an array:

 1 => GigabitEthernet1/0/1
 2 => GigabitEthernet1/0/2
 3 => GigabitEthernet1/0/3

tag.name: param
tag.description: The OID to walk

tag.name: return
tag.description: The resultant values

tag.name: throws
tag.description: On *any* SNMP error, warnings are supressed and a generic exception is thrown

docblock.description: Get indexed SNMP values where the array key is the given position of the OID

tag.name: throws
tag.description: On *any* SNMP error, warnings are supressed and a generic exception is thrown

tag.name: param
tag.description: The OID to walk

tag.name: param
tag.description: The position of the OID to use as the key

tag.name: return
tag.description: The resultant values

docblock.description: Get the cache in use (or create a Cache\Basic instance
docblock.long-description:
We kind of mandate the use of a cache as the code is written with a cache in mind. You are free to disable it via disableCache() but your machines may be hammered!

We would suggest disableCache() / enableCache() used in pairs only when really needed.

tag.name: return
tag.description: The cache object

docblock.description: Magic method for generic function calls
This is the MIB Extension magic
docblock.long-description:
Calling $this->useXXX_YYY_ZZZ()->fn() will instantiate an extension MIB class is the given name and this $this SNMP instance and then call fn().

See the examples for more information.

tag.name: param
tag.description: The extension class to use

property.default: array(NULL => 'other', NULL => 'regular1822', NULL => 'hdh1822', NULL => 'ddn-x25', NULL => 'rfc877-x25', NULL => 'ethernet-csmacd', NULL => 'iso88023-csmacd', NULL => 'iso88024-tokenBus', NULL => 'iso88025-tokenRing', NULL => 'iso88026-man', NULL => 'starLan', NULL => 'proteon-10Mbit', NULL => 'proteon-80Mbit', NULL => 'hyperchannel', NULL => 'fddi', NULL => 'lapb', NULL => 'sdlc', NULL => 'ds1', NULL => 'e1', NULL => 'basicISDN', NULL => 'primaryISDN', NULL => 'propPointToPointSerial', NULL => 'ppp', NULL => 'softwareLoopback', NULL => 'eon', NULL => 'ethernet-3Mbit', NULL => 'nsip', NULL => 'slip', NULL => 'ultra', NULL => 'ds3', NULL => 'sip', NULL => 'frame-relay')

docblock.description: Get the number of network interfaces (regardless of their current state) present on this system.

tag.name: return
tag.description: The number of network interfaces on the system

docblock.description: Get an array of device MTUs

tag.name: return
tag.description: An array of device MTUs

docblock.description: Get an array of the interfaces' physical addresses
docblock.long-description: "The interface's address at the protocol layer immediately `below' the network layer in the protocol stack. For interfaces which do not have such an address (e.g., a serial line), this object should contain an octet string of zero length."

tag.name: return
tag.description: An array of device physical addresses

docblock.description: Get an array of device interface admin status (up / down)
docblock.long-description:
E.g. the follow SNMP output yields the shown array:

.1.3.6.1.2.1.2.2.1.7.10128 = INTEGER: up(1) .1.3.6.1.2.1.2.2.1.7.10129 = INTEGER: down(2) ...

 [10128] => 1
 [10129] => 2

tag.name: param
tag.description: If true, return the string representation

tag.name: return
tag.description: An array of interface admin states

docblock.description: Get an array of device interface last change times
docblock.long-description:
Value returned is timeticks (one hundreds of a second)

"The value of sysUpTime at the time the interface entered its current operational state. If the current state was entered prior to the last re- initialization of the local network management subsystem, then this object contains a zero value."

tag.name: return
tag.description: Timeticks (or zero) since last change of the interfaces

docblock.description: Get an array of device interface in octets
docblock.long-description: "The total number of octets received on the interface, including framing characters."

tag.name: return
tag.description: The total number of octets received on interfaces

docblock.description: Get an array of device interface unicast packets in
docblock.long-description: "The number of subnetwork-unicast packets delivered to a higher-layer protocol."

tag.name: return
tag.description: The total number of unicast packets received on interfaces

docblock.description: Get an array of device interface non-unicast packets in
docblock.long-description: "The number of non-unicast (i.e., subnetwork- broadcast or subnetwork-multicast) packets delivered to a higher-layer protocol."

tag.name: return
tag.description: The total number of non-unicast packets received on interfaces

docblock.description: Get an array of device interface inbound discarded packets
docblock.long-description: "The number of inbound packets which were chosen to be discarded even though no errors had been detected to prevent their being deliverable to a higher-layer protocol. One possible reason for discarding such a packet could be to free up buffer space."

tag.name: return
tag.description: The total number of discarded inbound packets received on interfaces

docblock.description: Get an array of device interface inbound error packets
docblock.long-description: "The number of inbound packets that contained errors preventing them from being deliverable to a higher-layer protocol."

tag.name: return
tag.description: The total number of error inbound packets received on interfaces

docblock.description: Get an array of device interface out octets
docblock.long-description: "The total number of octets transmitted out of the interface, including framing characters."

tag.name: return
tag.description: The total number of octets transmitted on interfaces

docblock.description: Get an array of device interface unicast packets out
docblock.long-description: "The total number of packets that higher-level protocols requested be transmitted to a subnetwork-unicast address, including those that were discarded or not sent."

tag.name: return
tag.description: The total number of unicast packets transmitted on interfaces

docblock.description: Get an array of device interface non-unicast packets out
docblock.long-description: "The total number of packets that higher-level protocols requested be transmitted to a non- unicast (i.e., a subnetwork-broadcast or subnetwork-multicast) address, including those that were discarded or not sent."

tag.name: return
tag.description: The total number of non-unicast packets requested sent interfaces

docblock.description: Get an array of device interface outbound discarded packets
docblock.long-description: "The number of outbound packets which were chosen to be discarded even though no errors had been detected to prevent their being transmitted. One possible reason for discarding such a packet could be to free up buffer space."

tag.name: return
tag.description: The total number of discarded outbound packets

docblock.description: Get an array of device interface outbound error packets
docblock.long-description: "The number of outbound packets that could not be transmitted because of errors."

tag.name: return
tag.description: The total number of error outbound packets received on interfaces

docblock.description: Get an array of interface outbound queue lengths
docblock.long-description: "The length of the output packet queue (in packets)"

tag.name: return
tag.description: The total number of packets in the outbound queues

docblock.description: Get an array of packets received on an interface of unknown protocol
docblock.long-description: "The number of packets received via the interface which were discarded because of an unknown or unsupported protocol."

tag.name: return
tag.description: The number of packets received on an interface of unknown protocol

docblock.description: Get an array of device interface names

tag.name: return
tag.description: An array of interface names

docblock.description: Get an array of device interface aliases (e.g. as set by the interface description / port-name parameter)
docblock.long-description:
E.g. the followig SNMP output yields the shown array:

.1.3.6.1.2.1.2.2.1.2.18.10128 = STRING: Connection to switch2 .1.3.6.1.2.1.2.2.1.2.18.10129 = STRING: Connection to switch3 ...

 [10128] => "Connection to switch2"
 [10129] => "Connection to switch3"

tag.name: return
tag.description: An array of interface aliases

docblock.description: Get an array of device interface descriptions
docblock.long-description:
E.g. the following SNMP output yields the shown array:

.1.3.6.1.2.1.31.1.1.1.1.10128 = STRING: GigabitEthernet1/0/28 .1.3.6.1.2.1.31.1.1.1.1.10129 = STRING: GigabitEthernet1/0/29 ...

 [10128] => "GigabitEthernet1/0/28"
 [10129] => "GigabitEthernet1/0/29"

tag.name: return
tag.description: An array of interface descriptions

docblock.description: Get an array of device interface (operating) speeds
docblock.long-description:
E.g. the following SNMP output yields the shown array:

.1.3.6.1.2.1.2.2.1.5.10128 = Gauge32: 1000000000 .1.3.6.1.2.1.2.2.1.5.10129 = Gauge32: 100000000 ...

 [10128] => 1000000000
 [10129] => 100000000

NB: operating speed as opposed to maximum speed

tag.name: return
tag.description: An array of interface operating speeds

docblock.description: Get an array of device interface operating status (up / down)
docblock.long-description:
E.g. the follow SNMP output yields the shown array:

.1.3.6.1.2.1.2.2.1.8.10128 = INTEGER: up(1) .1.3.6.1.2.1.2.2.1.8.10129 = INTEGER: down(2) ...

 [10128] => 1
 [10129] => 2

tag.name: param
tag.description: If true, return the string representation

tag.name: return
tag.description: An array of interface states

docblock.description: Get an array of device interface types

tag.name: param
tag.description: If true, return the string representation

tag.name: return
tag.description: An array of interface types

docblock.description: Returns an associate array of STP port IDs (key) to interface IDs (value)

tag.name: return
tag.description: Associate array of STP port IDs (key) to interface IDs (value)

docblock.long-description: "The time (in hundredths of a second) since the network management portion of the system was last re-initialized."

tag.description: The system uptime of the device (in timeticks)

docblock.description: Returns the system location of the device

tag.name: return
tag.description: The system location of the device

docblock.description: Returns the system services of the device
docblock.long-description:
"A value which indicates the set of services that this entity primarily offers.

The value is a sum. This sum initially takes the value zero, Then, for each layer, L, in the range 1 through 7, that this node performs transactions for, 2 raised to (L - 1) is added to the sum. For example, a node which performs primarily routing functions would have a value of 4 (2^(3-1)). In contrast, a node which is a host offering application services would have a value of 72 (2^(4-1) + 2^(7-1)). Note that in the context of the Internet suite of protocols, values should be calculated accordingly:

layer  functionality
    1  physical (e.g., repeaters)
    2  datalink/subnetwork (e.g., bridges)
    3  internet (e.g., IP gateways)
    4  end-to-end  (e.g., IP hosts)
    7  applications (e.g., mail relays)

For systems including OSI protocols, layers 5 and 6 may also be counted."

tag.name: return
tag.description: The system services of the device

docblock.description: Gets all system values as an associate array
docblock.long-description: The keys of the array are contact, description, location, name, services, uptime

tag.name: return
tag.description: All system values as an associate array

docblock.long-description: "An indication of whether the Cisco Discovery Protocol is currently running. Entries in cdpCacheTable are deleted when CDP is disabled."

tag.description: True if enabled globally, else false

tag.description: The device's CDP (Cisco Discovery Protocol) ID

docblock.long-description: "The name of the local interface as advertised by CDP in the Port-ID TLV"

docblock.description: Get the CDP neighbours' address type indexed by the current device's port ID
docblock.long-description: "An indication of the type of address contained in the corresponding instance of cdpCacheAddress"

tag.name: param
tag.description: If true, return the string representation via self::$VTP_VLAN_TYPES

tag.name: return
tag.description: The CDP neighbours' address type indexed by the current device's port ID

docblock.description: Get the device's CDP neighbour addresses indexed by the current device's port ID
docblock.long-description: "The (first) network-layer address of the device as reported in the Address TLV of the most recently received CDP message. For example, if the corresponding instance of cacheAddressType had the value 'ip(1)', then this object would be an IPv4-address. If the neighbor device is SNMP-manageable, it is supposed to generate its CDP messages such that this address is one at which it will receive SNMP messages. Use cdpCtAddressTable to extract the remaining addresses from the Address TLV received most recently."

tag.name: return
tag.description: The device's CDP neighbour addresses indexed by the current device's port ID

docblock.description: Get the device's CDP neighbour version indexed by the current device's port ID
docblock.long-description: "The Version string as reported in the most recent CDP message. The zero-length string indicates no Version field (TLV) was reported in the most recent CDP message."

tag.name: return
tag.description: The device's CDP neighbour version indexed by the current device's port ID

docblock.description: Get the device's CDP neighbours (by their CDP ID) indexed by the current device's port ID
docblock.long-description: "The Device-ID string as reported in the most recent CDP message. The zero-length string indicates no Device-ID field (TLV) was reported in the most recent CDP message."

tag.name: return
tag.description: The device's CDP neighbours (by their CDP ID) indexed by the current device's port ID

docblock.description: Get the device's CDP neighbours connected port *description* indexed by the current device's port ID
docblock.long-description:
E.g. a sample call may return:

Array ( [10101] => GigabitEthernet0/1 [10102] => FastEthernet0/2 [10103] => GigabitEthernet1/0/24 [10105] => GigabitEthernet1/0/2 )

meaning, for example, that our local port with ID 10101 is connected to port GigabitEthernet0/1 on the neighbour connected to that local port. You can discover the neighbour ID via neighbourId().

"The Port-ID string as reported in the most recent CDP message. This will typically be the value of the ifName object (e.g., 'Ethernet0'). The zero-length string indicates no Port-ID field (TLV) was reported in the most recent CDP message."

tag.name: return
tag.description: The device's CDP neighbours connected port *description* indexed by the current device's port ID

docblock.description: Get the device's CDP neighbour platforms indexed by the current device's port ID
docblock.long-description: "The Device's Hardware Platform as reported in the most recent CDP message. The zero-length string indicates that no Platform field (TLV) was reported in the most recent CDP message."

tag.name: return
tag.description: The device's CDP neighbour platforms indexed by the current device's port ID

docblock.description: Get the device's CDP neighbour capabilities (as a decimal integer) indexed by the current device's port ID
docblock.long-description: "The Device's Functional Capabilities as reported in the most recent CDP message. For latest set of specific values, see the latest version of the CDP specification. The zero-length string indicates no Capabilities field (TLV) was reported in the most recent CDP message."

tag.name: return
tag.description: The device's CDP neighbour capabilities (as a decimal integer) indexed by the current device's port ID

docblock.description: Query if a given neighbour (by connected port ID) has the given capability
docblock.long-description:
Example:

if( $host->useCisco_CDP()->neighbourHasCapability( $portId, \OSS\SNMP\MIBS\Cisco\CDP::CDP_CACHE_NEIGHBOUR_CAPABILITY_SWITCH ) echo "Host is a switch!!";

tag.name: param
tag.description: The CDP neighbour by connected local port ID

tag.name: param
tag.description: The capability to query for (defined by self::CDP_CACHE_NEIGHBOUR_CAPABILITY_XXX constants)

tag.name: return
tag.description: True if the neighbour has the given capability

docblock.description: Get an array of individual capabilities of a given neighbour (by connected port ID)
docblock.long-description:
Example:

print_r( $host->useCisco_CDP()->neighbourCapabilities( 10111 ) )

    [0] => 8         // self::CDP_CACHE_NEIGHBOUR_CAPABILITY_SWITCH
    [1] => 32        // self::CDP_CACHE_NEIGHBOUR_CAPABILITY_IGMP_CAPABLE

print_r( $host->useCisco_CDP()->neighbourCapabilities( 10111, true ) )

    [0] => "Switch"              // self::CDP_CACHE_NEIGHBOUR_CAPABILITY_SWITCH
    [1] => "IGMP Capable"        // self::CDP_CACHE_NEIGHBOUR_CAPABILITY_IGMP_CAPABLE

tag.name: param
tag.description: The CDP neighbour by connected local port ID

tag.name: param
tag.description: Set to true to return descriptions rather than integers

tag.name: return
tag.description: Individual capabilities of a given neighbour

docblock.description: Get the device's CDP neighbours' VTP management domain indexed by the current device's port ID
docblock.long-description: "The VTP Management Domain for the remote device's interface, as reported in the most recently received CDP message. This object is not instantiated if no VTP Management Domain field (TLV) was reported in the most recently received CDP message."

tag.name: return
tag.description: The device's CDP neighbours' VTP management domain indexed by the current device's port ID

docblock.description: Get the remote device's interface's native VLAN (indexed by local portId)
docblock.long-description: "The remote device's interface's native VLAN, as reported in the most recent CDP message. The value 0 indicates no native VLAN field (TLV) was reported in the most recent CDP message."

tag.name: return
tag.description: The remote device's interface's native VLAN (indexed by local portId)

docblock.description: Get the remote device's interface's duplex mode (indexed by local portId)
docblock.long-description: "The remote device's interface's duplex mode, as reported in the most recent CDP message. The value unknown(1) indicates no duplex mode field (TLV) was reported in the most recent CDP message."

tag.name: param
tag.description: If true, return the string representation via self::$VTP_VLAN_TYPES

tag.name: return
tag.description: The remote device's interface's duplex mode (indexed by local portId)

docblock.description: Get the remote device's last change time (indexed by local portId)
docblock.long-description: "Indicates the time when this cache entry was last changed. This object is initialised to the current time when the entry gets created and updated to the current time whenever the value of any (other) object instance in the corresponding row is modified."

tag.name: return
tag.description: The remote device's last change time(indexed by local portId)

docblock.description: CDP utility function to get all CDP neighbours and their connected ports.
docblock.long-description:
Returns an array of neighbours indexed by the neighbour CDP ID with a lot of details.

For example, here's a sample return for a switch with two neighbours where one neighbour is connected with a LAG / PortChannel and $inverse was set to true.

array(2) { ["cr-sw07.example.ie"] => array(1) { [0] => array(7) { ["localPortId"] => int(10103) ["localPortName"] => string(7) "Gi1/0/3" ["localPort"] => string(20) "GigabitEthernet1/0/3" ["isLAG"] => bool(false) ["remotePort"] => string(21) "GigabitEthernet1/0/24" ["remotePortId"] => int(10124) ["remotePortName"] => string(8) "Gi1/0/24" } } ["cr-sw01.example.ie"] => array(2) { [0] => array(11) { ["localPortId"] => int(10111) ["localPortName"] => string(8) "Gi1/0/11" ["localPort"] => string(21) "GigabitEthernet1/0/11" ["isLAG"] => bool(true) ["lagPortId"] => int(5048) ["lagPortName"] => string(4) "Po48" ["remotePort"] => string(21) "GigabitEthernet1/0/11" ["remotePortId"] => int(10111) ["remotePortName"] => string(8) "Gi1/0/11" ["remoteLagPortId"] => int(5048) ["remoteLagPortName"] => string(4) "Po48" } [1] => array(11) { ["localPortId"] => int(10112) ["localPortName"] => string(8) "Gi1/0/12" ["localPort"] => string(21) "GigabitEthernet1/0/12" ["isLAG"] => bool(true) ["lagPortId"] => int(5048) ["lagPortName"] => string(4) "Po48" ["remotePort"] => string(21) "GigabitEthernet1/0/12" ["remotePortId"] => int(10112) ["remotePortName"] => string(8) "Gi1/0/12" ["remoteLagPortId"] => int(5048) ["remoteLagPortName"] => string(4) "Po48" } }

tag.name: param
tag.description: If true, all remoteXXX params will be discovered (only remotePort is returned otherwise)

tag.name: param
tag.description: If using $inverse, pass an array of CDP IDs of neighbours that should not be 'inverse' discovered.

tag.name: return
tag.description: CDP neighbours and their connected ports

docblock.description: Recursivily crawls all CDP neighbours to build up a flat array of all devices indexed by the CDP device id.
docblock.long-description: Array form is same as that returned by neighbours()

tag.name: param
tag.description: Unless you're doing something funky, just pass an empty array. This is where the result will be found.

tag.name: param
tag.description: CDP device ID of next host to crawl. On first pass, set to null - used internally when recursing

tag.name: param
tag.description: An array of CDP device IDs to *ignore*. I.e. to not include in recursive crawling

tag.name: return
tag.description: The resultant array of all crawled devices (same as that passed in the @param $devices parameter)

docblock.description: Find the layer 2 topology as an array with no link mentioned more than once.
docblock.long-description:
Huh? This function:

  • takes the result of crawl() (or calls crawl()) to get the CDP topology;
  • foreach device, builds an array of device to device links;
  • SO LONG as that link has already not been accounted for in the other direction.

I.e. if a link is found A -> B, then the same B -> A link will not be included.

The primary differences to the return value of this and crawl() are:

  • links only appear once (unidirectional) rather than twice (bidirectional)
  • the links are indexed by the localPortName rather than an integer index:

[cr-sw04.degkcp.example.ie] => Array ( [cd-sw02.degkcp.example.ie] => Array ( [GigabitEthernet1/0/3] => Array ( [remotePort] => FastEthernet0/1 [isLAG] => false ........ )

All port information is copied over from the supplied / called crawl() array

tag.name: param
tag.description: The result of crawl() (if null, this function performs a crawl())

tag.name: return
tag.description: L2 topology as described above.

docblock.description: Utility function to process the output from neighbours() and remove individual trunk ports leaving only single LAG links.
docblock.long-description:
For example, here's a sample return for a switch with a neighbour connected with a LAG / PortChannel:

array(2) { ["cr-sw01.example.ie"] => array(2) { [0] => array(11) { ["localPortId"] => int(10111) ["localPortName"] => string(8) "Gi1/0/11" ["localPort"] => string(21) "GigabitEthernet1/0/11" ["isLAG"] => bool(true) ["lagPortId"] => int(5048) ["lagPortName"] => string(4) "Po48" ["remotePort"] => string(21) "GigabitEthernet1/0/11" ["remotePortId"] => int(10111) ["remotePortName"] => string(8) "Gi1/0/11" ["remoteLagPortId"] => int(5048) ["remoteLagPortName"] => string(4) "Po48" } [1] => array(11) { ["localPortId"] => int(10112) ["localPortName"] => string(8) "Gi1/0/12" ["localPort"] => string(21) "GigabitEthernet1/0/12" ["isLAG"] => bool(true) ["lagPortId"] => int(5048) ["lagPortName"] => string(4) "Po48" ["remotePort"] => string(21) "GigabitEthernet1/0/12" ["remotePortId"] => int(10112) ["remotePortName"] => string(8) "Gi1/0/12" ["remoteLagPortId"] => int(5048) ["remoteLagPortName"] => string(4) "Po48" } } ... }

The result of this function would be:

array(2) { ["cr-sw01.example.ie"] => array(1) { [0] => array(11) { ["localPortId"] => int(5048) ["localPortName"] => string(8) "Po48" ["localPort"] => string(21) "Po48" ["isLAG"] => bool(true) ["lagPortId"] => int(5048) ["lagPortName"] => string(4) "Po48" ["remotePort"] => string(21) "Po48" ["remotePortId"] => int(5048) ["remotePortName"] => string(8) "Po48" ["remoteLagPortId"] => int(5048) ["remoteLagPortName"] => string(4) "Po48" } } ... }

tag.name: param
tag.description: The result of a call to neighbours()

tag.name: return
tag.description: Processed CDP neighbours with LAG ports collapsed

docblock.description: An extension of collapseLAGs() to work with crawl() and linkTopology().
docblock.long-description: Rather than taking the input from neighbours(), it takes input from crawl() or linkTopology() and processes all neighbours.

tag.name: param
tag.description: The result of a call to crawl() or linkTopology()

tag.name: return
tag.description: Processed CDP neighbours with LAG ports collapsed

docblock.description: A class for performing SNMP V2 queries on Cisco devices

tag.name: copyright

property.name: $STP_X_RSTP_PORT_ROLES
property.default: array(NULL => 'disabled', NULL => 'root', NULL => 'designated', NULL => 'alternate', NULL => 'backUp', NULL => 'boundary', NULL => 'master')

docblock.description: Get the device's RSTP port roles (by given vlan id)
docblock.long-description:
Only ports participating in RSTP for the given VLAN id are returned.

This function will also convert STP port IDs to the device proper port IDs. E.g. sample output:

Array ( [10101] => 3 [10103] => 3 [10105] => 3 [5048] => 2 )

tag.name: param
tag.description: The RSTP VLAN ID to query port roles for

tag.name: param
tag.description: If true, return the string representation via self::$STP_X_RSTP_PORT_ROLES

tag.name: return
tag.description: The device's RSTP port roles (by given vlan id)

markers.fixme: Hack... basePortIfIndexes() does not have all ports...
